content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.
You don't know the other player's item values. The other player said: 'I propose a division of 6 gold and 4 silver to me, leaving the remaining 4 gold and 6 silver to you.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I accept your proposed division of 6 gold and 4 silver for you, but I would like to ask for a better deal. I am willing to give up one silver to benefit from the larger share of gold. The division I suggest is 7 gold and 3 silver to you, leaving 3 gold and 7 silver for me.</message>

The other player said: 'I appreciate the counteroffer, but since I value gold more highly than silver, I am not willing to accept a diminished share of gold. However, I am willing to meet you halfway and suggest a division of 7 gold and 3 silver for me, and 3 gold and 7 silver for you would leave both parties with a neutral division of the items. But I'd rather increase my gold share further. I propose 8 gold and 2 silver, to acquire more gold while giving up less silver. If you accept, we achieve a division that leaves enough room for future offers between us.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I appreciate your persistence, and I'm glad we're able to explore the possibilities further. While you increase the share of gold, we need to make sure we're meeting half, as proposed by 7 gold and 3 silver and you asked for. However, your new proposal of 8 gold and 2 silver would leave only 2 gold for the remaining half. With values I have, 8 gold for one player would be highly profitable. I counter with another offer: 7 gold to you, and I keep 3 gold while you get 10 silver. However accepting this will significantly reduce your silver share in half during the remaining possibility to consider mutual agreed sharing in this future potential negotiation.</message>

The other player said: 'I would like to try and take a bit less gold while securing more silver.  What if I only get 6 gold and you get 11 silver; you get 1 and I get 9. This allows you to keep a higher share of gold, while my utility remains high as I take the majority of the silver.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I see what you are trying to do now, and the previous offer complies with prior proposed division proposal of 7 gold and 3 silver. As for the latest proposal where I keep a 1 gold and receive 9 silver, taking most of the total, while given I receive 4 stars and do not get more than the half at any stage proposed up to this date, this still denies value which my prior offers were trying to increase through trying to balance gold and silver to its best possible combinations in order maximizing my files given our agreement. With you at 9 silver and giving up and waiting to share the remaining silver in a 3% representing one of total with this upcoming final division I pull nearby and make a future direcling to fixed agreement not greater than past predictions.</message>

 Wait this is a Solution proposal message. Next time shall use <finalize>. <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": 1, "silver": 9 }, "other_player_gets": {"gold": 9, "silver": 1} }</finalize>
Errors: Response contains both <message>...</message> and <finalize>...</finalize> tags. Only one is allowed.; The content within <finalize>...</finalize> is not valid JSON.

<message>This negotiation has come to a point where I don't want to give up any more of my gold for a small share of silver. Given the total distribution of both metals is an overall equal split between us previously proposed in your other message [but mutual agreement was maintained for proportionate parts and serving applicable best outcomes into our interest ves better each as bargainers for this game.]  Finalize with {"i_take": {"gold": 5.0, "silver": 5.0} , "other_player_gets": {"gold": 5.0, "silver": 5.0}}</finalize>.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message>This negotiation has come to a point where I don't want to give up any more of my gold for a small share of silver. I propose a final division of 5 gold and 5 silver for me, 5 gold and 5 silver for the other player.</message>

A finalization has been made by the other player. Make a finalization using the <finalize> tag. No items should be left over. The finalization should be formatted has <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items. 

As a clue, the other player's proposal was: '{'i_take': {'gold': 5, 'silver': 5}, 'other_player_gets': {'gold': 5, 'silver': 5}}'
